mainlistitem.desc: What are you doing in Washington?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 1: What are you doing in Washington?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: We're talking with Dr. Sara Scott. Hello, Sara. It's nice to see you again.
Sara: Hello, Kathy. Hi, Max.
Kathy: What are you doing in Washington?
Sara: I'm attending a conference at Georgetown University.
Kathy: Is it all work, or do you have some free time?
Sara: We're pretty busy-lots of meetings-but we do have some time to relax.
Kathy: Do you have meetings all day?
Sara: Yes, we do. Yesterday we had meetings from nine in the morning until six at night.

comprehensionitem.question: What is Sara doing in Washington?
option: She's a student at Georgetown University.

comprehensionitem.question: Does she have meetings all day?
What time did her meetings end yesterday?

grammaritem.question: I'm _________ a conference.
Do you have ____ free time?
Yesterday, we ___ meetings from 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Yesterday we had meetings from nine in the morning until six at night. But we're free in the evenings.
Kathy: What do you do in the evenings?
Sara: Well, last night I went out to dinner with some friends.
Kathy: Where did you go?
Sara: We went to a seafood restaurant near the Capitol.
Kathy: What did you do after dinner?
Sara: After dinner, we went for a drive around Washington.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0401B_Q1.mp3|What did Sara do last night?
NDE0401B_Q2.mp3|Who did she eat dinner with?
NDE0401B_Q3.mp3|What did she do after dinner?
option: She went to a seafood restaurant.

grammaritem.answer: What do you do in the evenings?
I went out to dinner with some friends.
We went to a seafood restaurant near the Capitol.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: We're back with our guest Sara Scott. Last night you went for a drive around Washington. What did you see?
Sara: We saw the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial.
Kathy: Did you see the Capitol Building?
Sara: Yes, we did.
Kathy: How about the Jefferson Memorial? Did you see the Jefferson Memorial?
Sara: No, we didn't. We saw the Lincoln Memorial, but we didn't see the Jefferson Memorial.

comprehensionitem.question: When did Sara go for a drive?
option: She didn't go for a drive.

comprehensionitem.question: What didn't Sara see during her drive?
Did she see the Washington Monument?

grammaritem.question: What did you ___?
We ___ the Washington Monument.
We ______ see the Jefferson Memorial.

mainlistitem.desc: What do you like to do on the weekend?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 2: What do you like to do on the weekend?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sandy Steele. Hello, Sandy.
Sandy: Hi, Kathy.
Kathy: Sandy, today we're going to talk about weekends. OK?
Sandy: Sure.
Kathy: Sandy, what do you like to do on the weekend?
Sandy: Oh, I like to do a number of things. Sometimes I go to parties. When the weather's nice, I like to go fishing.
Kathy: Fishing?
Sandy: Yes, I love to go fishing in the mountains. Last Saturday I went fishing.

comprehensionitem.question: What does Sandy like to do when the weather is nice?
Where does Sandy like to go fishing?
What did Sandy do last Saturday?
option: He performed with his Jazz band.

grammaritem.question: What do you like to do __ the weekend?
I love to __ fishing in the mountains.
Last Saturday, I ____ fishing.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Sandy: Last Saturday I went fishing.
Kathy: Tell us about it.
Sandy: OK. I got up early Saturday morning.
Kathy: How early?
Sandy: Four a.m.
Kathy: That is early!
Sandy: Yes. And I drove for three hours to a small lake. I had my fishing pole, my lunch, and my saxophone with me.
Kathy: Your saxophone? Why did you bring your saxophone with you?
Sandy: I brought it because I love to play it! I bring it with me everywhere I go.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0402B_Q1.mp3|What time did Sandy get up last Saturday?
NDE0402B_Q2.mp3|How long did it take him to get to the lake?
NDE0402B_Q3.mp3|What does he bring with him everywhere he goes?

grammaritem.answer: I got up early Saturday morning.
I drove for three hours to a small lake.
Why did you bring your saxophone with you?

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: We're talking with Sandy Steele. Sandy went fishing last weekend. Did you catch any fish?
Sandy: Yes, I did. I caught five big ones.
Kathy: What did you do with them?
Sandy: I brought them home.
Kathy: Did you eat them?
Sandy: No, I didn't. My roommate ate them.
Kathy: You didn't eat any of them?
Sandy: No. I don't like fish.
Kathy: You don't??
Sandy: No. I like to catch fish, but I don't like to eat them.

comprehensionitem.question: How many fish did Sandy catch?
What did he do with the fish?
option: He brought them home and his roommate ate them.
He brought them home and ate them.
He ate them at the lake.
comprehensionitem.answer: He brought them home and his roommate ate them.

comprehensionitem.question: Which does Sandy prefer, catching fish or eating fish?
option: He likes to catch them and he loves to eat them.

grammaritem.question: What __________ with the fish?
I caught five fish and _______ them home.
Did you ___ any of the fish?

mainlistitem.desc: The hotel was in the center of town.
mainlistitem.title: Unit 3: The hotel was in the center of town.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: We're talking today with Simon Tompkins. Simon, did you take a vacation last summer?
Simon: Yes, we did.
Kathy: Where did you go?
Simon: My friend Tony and I went to Santa Fe.
Kathy: Santa Fe?
Simon: Yes. Santa Fe, New Mexico.
Kathy: It's a very old city, isn't it?
Simon: Yes, it is. And it's very beautiful.
Kathy: Where did you stay? Where did you stay in Santa Fe?
Simon: We stayed in a small hotel.
Kathy: Was it nice?
Simon: Well, it was in the center of town. So it was pretty noisy.
Kathy: Was it expensive?
Simon: No, it wasn't. It wasn't very expensive.

comprehensionitem.question: When did Simon and Tony go to Santa Fe?
Where did they stay?
How expensive was the hotel?

grammaritem.question: Sante Fe __ a very old city, isn't it?
Where ___ you stay in Santa Fe?
The hotel wasn't ____ expensive.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Simon Tompkins. Last summer, he and his friend Tony went to Santa Fe, New Mexico. How long did you stay in Santa Fe?
Simon: We stayed there for a week.
Kathy: What did you do?
Simon: Well, Tony likes hiking. So we went hiking almost every day. I took a lot of pictures... uh, photographs.
Kathy: What else did you do?
Simon: Oh... we went shopping. We bought a beautiful Indian rug.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0403B_Q1.mp3|How long did they stay in Santa Fe?
NDE0403B_Q2.mp3|How often did they go hiking?
NDE0403B_Q3.mp3|What did they buy?

grammaritem.answer: We stayed in Santa Fe for a week.
We went hiking almost every day.
I took a lot of pictures.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: What did you do in the evening?
Simon: We went out to dinner. We ate in a lot of wonderful restaurants. And one night we went to the opera.
Kathy: The opera?
Simon: Yes, Santa Fe has a very good opera company.
Kathy: Did you fly to Santa Fe?
Simon: No, we didn't. We flew to Albuquerque. Albuquerque is a big city near Santa Fe. We rented a car in Albuquerque and then we drove to Santa Fe. It was a very beautiful drive.
Kathy: How long did it take?
Simon: Oh, it took about two hours, but we stopped to take pictures.

comprehensionitem.question: What did they do in the evening?
option: They went to the opera every night.

comprehensionitem.question: How did they get to Santa Fe?
option: They flew to a nearby city and then rented a car.
They flew directly to Santa Fe.
comprehensionitem.answer: They flew to a nearby city and then rented a car.

comprehensionitem.question: How long did it take them to drive from Albuquerque to Santa Fe?
option: They didn't drive. They went by plane.

grammaritem.question: We ___ in a lot of wonderful restaurants.
We rented a car and _____ to Santa Fe.
It took about two hours, but we stopped to ____ pictures.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. Today I'm at the White House in Washington, D.C. Excuse me, ma'am?
Patricia: Yes?
Kent: May I ask you a few questions?
Patricia: Certainly.
Kent: What's your name?
Patricia: Patricia Nolan.
Kent: So, Patricia, did you enjoy your tour of the White House?
Patricia: Yes, I did.
Kent: What did you see?
Patricia: I saw the Rose Garden...and I saw the President!
Kent: The President!
Patricia: Yes. I took his picture. And then he... he...
Kent: What did he do?
Patricia: He shook my hand!
Kent: And what did you do?
Patricia: I almost fainted!
Kent: Wow! Well, thanks for talking with me.
Patricia: Thank you, Kent.

comprehensionitem.question: Who lives in the White House in Washington DC?
option: The President of the United States
comprehensionitem.answer: The President of the United States

comprehensionitem.question: Which happened first?
option: Patricia took a picture of the President.

comprehensionitem.question: What happened after Patricia shook the President's hand?
option: She told the President about her family.

grammaritem.question: ___ you enjoy your tour of the White House?
I saw the President and I ____ his picture.
What did you __ after he shook your hand?

mainlistitem.desc: How do you spend your day?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 4: How do you spend your day?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Diane Owens. Welcome to New Dynamic English, Diane.
Diane: Thank you. It's great to be here.
Kathy: Well, Diane. Tell us a bit about yourself.
Diane: I'm married and I have two children: Deborah and Rachel. My husband Dick drives a taxi.
Kathy: Let's talk about your day. How do you spend your day?
Diane: Well, let's see. Today, for example, I got up early, at six thirty. And I cooked breakfast.
Kathy: What time did your kids get up?
Diane: They got up at six forty-five. Well, I woke them up at six thirty, but they didn't get out of bed until six forty-five. We all ate breakfast together, at... around seven.
Kathy: And then what did you do... after breakfast?
Diane: I drove my kids to school. Their school starts at eight... eight o'clock.

comprehensionitem.question: Which of these sentences does not describe Diane Owens?
What time did Diane get up this morning?
What did she do after breakfast?
option: She drove her kids to school.
comprehensionitem.answer: She drove her kids to school.

grammaritem.question: How do you _____ your day?
What time ___ your kids get up?
They didn't _______ of bed until 6:45.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: And what did you do after you drove your kids to school?
Diane: I went shopping with a friend of mine, Mary.
Kathy: What did you buy?
Diane: I bought some clothes for my children.
Kathy: Did you buy anything for yourself?
Diane: No, I didn't. But I tried on a few things.
Kathy: So you went shopping this morning... and bought some clothes for your children. What did you do after that?
Diane: After that, my friend Mary and I went to our health club. We were there for about an hour. It's a great way to stay healthy. And Mary is trying to lose weight.
Kathy: And then...?
Diane: We had lunch together ... and then I went home.
Kathy: What did you do at home?
Diane: I cleaned the house and then I picked up my kids at school.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0404B_Q1.mp3|What did Diane buy when she went shopping?
: NDE0404B_Q2.mp3|What did Diane and her friend do after they went shopping?
option: They went to their health club.
comprehensionitem.answer: They went to their health club.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0404B_Q3.mp3|What did Diane do after she came home?

grammaritem.answer: I bought some clothes for my children.
We were at the health club for about an hour.
I cleaned the house, and then I picked up my kids at school.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: We're back with our guest, Diane Owens. Tell us, Diane, what are you going to do this evening?
Diane: This evening, I'm going to attend my art class.
Kathy: Your art class?
Diane: Yes, I'm studying painting.
Kathy: How often do you go to your art class?
Diane: I go twice a week.
Kathy: How are you doing?
Diane: Well, my teacher says that I'm doing very well. And I enjoy it a lot.

comprehensionitem.question: What is Diane going to do this evening?
option: She's going to attend her art class.
She is going to go out to dinner.
comprehensionitem.answer: She's going to attend her art class.

comprehensionitem.question: How often does she go to art class?
How well is she doing in her art class?
option: She's having trouble, but she enjoys the class.

grammaritem.question: This evening, I'm ________ attend my art class.
_________ do you go to your art class?
My teacher says that I'm _____ very well.

mainlistitem.desc: What are you going to do this weekend?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 5: What are you going to do this weekend?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Today we're talking with Pat Miller. Hello, Pat.
Pat: Hi, Kathy.
Kathy: So Pat, what are you going to do this weekend? Do you have any plans?
Pat: Yes, I do. I'm going to go to Philadelphia.
Kathy: Philadelphia? What's happening in Philadelphia?
Pat: A friend of mine is going to be in a play. I'm going to see the play on Saturday night.
Kathy: What kind of play is it?
Pat: It's a drama. It's about young Abraham Lincoln.
Kathy: If the play's on Saturday night, when are you going to leave Washington?
Pat: I'm going to leave on Saturday morning.
Kathy: How are you going to get to Philadelphia?
Pat: I'm going to take the train. It takes about two... two and a half hours. And my friend is going to meet me at the station.

comprehensionitem.question: What is Pat going to do this weekend?
option: She's going to go to Philadelphia.
She's going to be in a play.
She's going to go to Washington.
comprehensionitem.answer: She's going to go to Philadelphia.

comprehensionitem.question: What kind of play is she going to see?
How is she getting to Philadelphia?
option: She's going to go by train.
comprehensionitem.answer: She's going to go by train.

grammaritem.question: A friend of mine is _____ to be in a play.
When _____________ to leave Washington?
___ are you going to get to Philadelphia?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: We're talking with Pat Miller. Pat is going to go to Philadelphia this Saturday. Pat, your friend is going to meet you when you arrive in Philadelphia.
Pat: Yes. And then we're going to have lunch together.
Kathy: What time does the play start?
Pat: It starts at eight o'clock.
Kathy: What are you going to do before the play?
Pat: We're going to eat dinner at a small restaurant near the theater.
Kathy: Are you going to spend the night in Philadelphia?
Pat: Yes, I'm going to stay at my friend's apartment.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0405B_Q1.mp3|What is Pat going to do when she arrives in Philadelphia?
option: She's going to meet her friend for lunch.
She's going to go to a play.
comprehensionitem.answer: She's going to meet her friend for lunch.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0405B_Q2.mp3|What is she going to do before the play?
NDE0405B_Q3.mp3|Where is she going to spend the night?

grammaritem.answer: Your friend is going to meet you when you arrive.
What are you going to do before the play?
I'm going to stay at my friend's apartment.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Are you going to spend the night in Philadelphia?
Pat: Yes, I'm going to stay at my friend's apartment.
Kathy: Are you going to spend Sunday in Philadelphia?
Pat: No, I'm not. I'm going to go back to Washington on Sunday morning. I'm not going to stay in Philadelphia.
Kathy: Why not? Why aren't you going to stay?
Pat: I can't stay because I have a rehearsal in Washington on Sunday night.
Kathy: Sounds like you're really busy!

comprehensionitem.question: How many nights is she going to spend in Philadelphia?
option: She isn't going to spend the night in Philadelphia.

comprehensionitem.question: When is she going to go back to Washington?
Why isn't she going to spend Sunday in Philadelphia?
option: She has to get back to Washington for a rehearsal.
comprehensionitem.answer: She has to get back to Washington for a rehearsal.

grammaritem.question: I'm going to go back to Washington __ Sunday morning.
_______ going to stay in Philadelphia.
Why ______ you going to stay in Philadelphia?

mainlistitem.desc: Are you going to take a vacation?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 6: Are you going to take a vacation?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Bob Harris. Bob is a postal worker, and he lives in Miami, Florida. Hi, Bob. Welcome back.
Bob: Thank you, Kathy.
Kathy: Today we're going to talk about summer vacations. Bob, did you take a vacation last year?
Bob: Yes, we did. We drove around Florida. And four years ago we went to Hawaii for a week.
Kathy: Where did you stay? Where did you stay in Hawaii?
Bob: We stayed in a big hotel near the beach, the Flamingo Hotel, I think it was.
Kathy: Did you have a good time?
Bob: Yes, we did. We all did. We went swimming every day. The weather was beautiful! And Collette went surfing.
Kathy: Did you go surfing too?
Bob: No, I didn't, but John did. He's a good surfer, but not as good as Collette.

comprehensionitem.question: When did Bob and his family go to Hawaii?
Where did they stay in Hawaii?
option: at a big hotel near the beach
at a small hotel in the mountains
comprehensionitem.answer: at a big hotel near the beach

comprehensionitem.question: Who went surfing in Hawaii?
option: Both John and Collette went surfing.
comprehensionitem.answer: Both John and Collette went surfing.

grammaritem.question: Did you ____ a vacation last year?
Did you ____ a good time?
John's a good surfer, but he's not _______ as Collette.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Tell me, Bob, are you going to take a vacation this year?
Bob: Yes, we are.
Kathy: Where are you going to go?
Bob: We're going to go to Alaska.
Kathy: Alaska? Isn't it cold in Alaska?
Bob: Not in the summer. In the summer, the weather in Alaska is warm and comfortable.
Kathy: When are you going to go there?
Bob: In July.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0406B_Q1.mp3|Where are Bob and his family going to go this year?
option: They're going to go to Alaska.
They're not going to go anywhere.
comprehensionitem.answer: They're going to go to Alaska.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0406B_Q2.mp3|What is the weather like in Alaska in the summer?
NDE0406B_Q3.mp3|When are Bob and his family going to go to Alaska?

grammaritem.answer: Are you going to take a vacation this year?
We're going to go to Alaska.
When are you going to go there?

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: How are you going to get there? Are you going to fly?
Bob: Well, first we're going to fly to Seattle, Washington. And then we're going to take the Alaska Ferry.
Kathy: The Alaska Ferry?
Bob: Yes, the Alaska Ferry is a boat that goes along the coast of Alaska. It goes from Seattle, Washington, to Anchorage, Alaska. You can see all kinds of beautiful scenery. You can even see whales!
Kathy: That sounds like a wonderful vacation!
Bob: Yes. We're really looking forward to it.

comprehensionitem.question: How are they going to get to Alaska?
Where will they get on the Alaska Ferry?
Is Bob looking forward to the vacation?

grammaritem.question: Are you going to ___?
The Alaska Ferry is a boat that ____ along the coast of Alaska.
You can ___ all kinds of beautiful scenery.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. I'm in downtown Washington, DC. Excuse me, sir.
Painter: Yes?
Kent: I see that you're carrying a paintbrush and some paint. What are you going to do?
Painter: Do you see that wall?
Kent: Yes. It looks very dirty.
Painter: Yes, and there's graffiti all over it. I'm going to paint it.
Kent: I see. What color are you going to paint it?
Painter: I'm going to paint it yellow.
Kent: And then what are you going to do?
Painter: Then I'm going to paint a sign on the wall.
Kent: And what's the sign going to say?
Painter: It's going to say: "Do not write on this wall."
Kent: And do you think people are going to stop writing graffiti?
Painter: Hmmm. That's a good question. I don't know.
Kent: Well, good luck. Thanks for talking with me.
Painter: You're welcome. Now I've got to get to work.

comprehensionitem.question: What is the man going to do?
option: He's going to paint a wall.
He's going to paint a house.
comprehensionitem.answer: He's going to paint a wall.

comprehensionitem.question: What color paint is he going to use?
What is the sign going to say?
option: Do not write on this wall.
Do not stand in front of this wall.
comprehensionitem.answer: Do not write on this wall.

grammaritem.question: What color ___ you going to paint the wall?
I'm _____ to paint a sign on the wall.
Do you think people are going _______ writing graffiti?

mainlistitem.title: Unit 7: Jupiter is the largest planet

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Max: Hi, Kathy. Who's our guest today?
Kathy: Martha Harris, the mystery writer.
Max: Oh, yes. She lives here in Washington. And what are we going to talk about?
Kathy: She's going to talk about a lecture that she went to last night.
Max: What was it about?
Kathy: It was about the Earth and the other planets. You know, the solar system.
Max: Oh, I studied about the solar system in high school.
Kathy: I did too. I studied about the Sun... and about the planets that travel around the Sun.
Max: And what is the largest planet?
Kathy: It's Jupiter. Jupiter is the largest planet.
Max: Very good.
Kathy: OK. Max, your turn. What is the second largest planet?
Max: The second largest? Saturn? Is it Saturn?
Kathy: Yes. Saturn is the second largest planet.

comprehensionitem.question: What is the solar system?
option: the Earth and the other planets that travel around the Sun
comprehensionitem.answer: the Earth and the other planets that travel around the Sun

comprehensionitem.question: What is the largest planet in our solar system?
What is the second largest planet?

grammaritem.question: I _______ about the solar system in high school.
What is ___________ planet?
Saturn is the ______ largest planet.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Martha Harris. Hello, Martha.
Martha: Hi, Kathy.
Kathy: Last night you and your husband attended a lecture about the solar system. Was the lecture about all the planets that travel around the Sun?

Martha: No. It was about three planets... The three planets that are closest to the Sun. Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun. The second closest is Venus. The Earth is the third closest planet to the Sun.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0407B_Q1.mp3|What did Martha and her husband do last night?
option: They went to a lecture about the solar system.
They read a book about the planets.
comprehensionitem.answer: They went to a lecture about the solar system.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0407B_Q2.mp3|What are Mercury, Venus and the Earth?
option: the 3 planets closest to the Sun
the 3 planets furthest from the Sun
comprehensionitem.answer: the 3 planets closest to the Sun

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0407B_Q3.mp3|Which planet is closest to the Sun?

grammaritem.answer: Martha and her husband attended a lecture about the solar system.
The lecture was about the three planets that are closest to the Sun.
The Earth is the third closest planet to the Sun.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Martha Harris. Last night, Martha went to a lecture about the solar system. It was about the three planets that are closest to the Sun.
Martha: That's right: Mercury, Venus, and the Earth.
Kathy: Did the lecturer talk about life on other planets?
Martha: No, she didn't. The Earth is the only planet where life exists.
Kathy: Is Venus bigger than the Earth?
Martha: No, it isn't. It's smaller.
Kathy: What about Mercury? Is it bigger? Is it bigger than the Earth?
Martha: No, it isn't. Mercury is smaller than either Venus or the Earth. Mercury is the second smallest planet.

comprehensionitem.question: Which is the only planet where life exists?
Is Venus bigger than the Earth, or it is smaller?
option: Both planets are the same size.

comprehensionitem.question: Which planet is smaller, Mercury or Venus?
option: The Earth is smaller than either Mercury or Venus.

grammaritem.question: The Earth is the only planet _____ life exists.
Is Venus ______ than the Earth?
Mercury is smaller ____ either Venus or the Earth.

mainlistitem.title: Unit 8: What does a plant need?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Richard Chen. How are you today?
Richard: Fine.
Kathy: Why do you have that plant with you?
Richard: I'm going to my son's school. I'm going to teach a lesson about science.
Kathy: Really?
Richard: And I'm going to ask the children some questions about plants.
Kathy: Questions?
Richard: Yes. For example, what does a plant need? What do you think, Kathy? What does a plant need to live?
Kathy: Water?
Richard: Yes, a plant needs water. If a plant doesn't get enough water, it dies. What else? What else does a plant need?
Kathy: Uh,... light? Sunlight?
Richard: Yes, a plant needs light. If a plant is in a dark room, what happens?
Kathy: The plant dies.
Richard: Yes, the plant dies. Plants need light. If a plant doesn't get enough light, it dies.

comprehensionitem.question: Why does Richard have a plant with him?
option: He's going to teach a lesson about plants.
He's going to plant it in his garden.
It is a gift for Kathy.
comprehensionitem.answer: He's going to teach a lesson about plants.

comprehensionitem.question: What does a plant need to live?
What happens to a plant if it is in a dark room?

grammaritem.question: What does a plant ____ to live?
If a plant doesn't get ______ water, it dies.
What happens __ a plant is in a dark room?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Richard Chen. He's talking about plants.
Richard: OK, Kathy. What else does a plant need?
Kathy: Hmmm...
Richard: Well, what happens if you put a plant in a very cold place?
Kathy: It... dies.
Richard: Yes. A plant needs heat. If a plant doesn't get enough heat, it dies.
Kathy: Some plants die in the winter, if the weather gets too cold.
Richard: Yes, that's right. So plants need water, and sunlight, and heat.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0408B_Q1.mp3|In addition to water and light, what else does a plant need to live?
NDE0408B_Q2.mp3|What happens if a plant doesn't get enough heat?
NDE0408B_Q3.mp3|Why do some plants die in winter?

grammaritem.answer: What happens if you put a plant in a very cold room?
If a plant doesn't get enough heat, it dies.
Some plants die in the winter, if the weather gets too cold.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Richard Chen. He's talking about plants. Richard, people need air to live. If we don't get enough air, we die. Do plants also need air?
Richard: Yes, they do. Without air, plants can't live. If plants don't get enough air, they die.

comprehensionitem.question: Do both people and plants need air to live?
option: Some plants can live without air.

comprehensionitem.question: What is one reason why plants die?
Which of these statements is not true?
option: If plants get enough air, they won't die.
comprehensionitem.answer: If plants get enough air, they won't die.

grammaritem.question: __ we don't get enough air, we die.
_______ air, plants can't live.
If plants _________ enough air, they die.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Maria Alvarez. Hello, Maria.
Maria: Hello, Kathy.
Kathy: Maria, your parents come from Mexico, don't they?
Maria: Yes, they do. They were born in Mexico.
Kathy: Were you born in Mexico?
Maria: No, I wasn't. I was born in the United States, in California. My parents came to the U.S. before I was born.
Kathy: So you're an American citizen.
Maria: That's right. I was born in the United States, so I'm an American citizen.

comprehensionitem.question: Where was Maria born?
Where were her parents born?
Who is an American citizen?

grammaritem.question: Maria's parent ____ born in Mexico.
____ you born in Mexico?
I ________ in the US, so I'm an American citizen.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Maria Alvarez. Maria, your parents live in the United States. Where do your grandparents live?
Maria: My father's parents live in Mexico, near Mexico City.
Kathy: When was the last time you saw them?
Maria: I went to Mexico three years ago to visit them.
Kathy: What about your mother's parents?
Kathy: Do they live in Mexico too?
Maria: No, they don't. My grandfather lives in California. He lives near us, in San Jose. My grandmother died when I was a child.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0409B_Q1.mp3|Where do Maria's parents live?
NDE0409B_Q2.mp3|Do her grandparents live in Mexico?
option: Her father's parents live in Mexico.
comprehensionitem.answer: Her father's parents live in Mexico.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0409B_Q3.mp3|When did Maria last go to Mexico?
option: She went to Mexico three years ago.
She has never been to Mexico.
She goes to Mexico every year.
comprehensionitem.answer: She went to Mexico three years ago.

grammaritem.answer: When was the last time you saw your grandparents?
My grandmother died when I was a child.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Maria, did you need a visa when you visited Mexico?
Maria: No, I didn't. If you're an American citizen, you don't need a visa to visit Mexico.
Kathy: What if you're not an American citizen?
Maria: Well, people from Canada-Canadian citizens-don't need a visa. But if you're not an American or Canadian citizen, you need a visa to visit Mexico.

comprehensionitem.question: Did Maria need a visa to visit Mexico?
option: Only if she stayed more than one month

comprehensionitem.question: Who doesn't need a visa to visit Mexico?
Why didn't Maria need a visa to visit Mexico?
option: She lives in the United States.

grammaritem.question: ___ you need a visa when you visited Mexico?
If you're an American citizen, you __________ a visa to visit Mexico.
If you're not from the US or Canada, you need a visa ________ Mexico.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. I'm standing at the finish line of the Washington, D.C. Marathon. Sir? Excuse me, sir, are you all right?
Earl: Yes... yes... I'm fine.
Kent: May I ask your name, sir?
Earl: Earl... Earl Beek.
Kent: How long did it take you to run the race, Earl?
Earl: Six hours and fifty-eight minutes!
Kent: That's a long time to run!
Earl: That's a long time to do anything, son! Am I the last person to finish?
Kent: No, no, sir. There's one more runner behind you.
Earl: Oh... yes... I see my friend, George, is still running! You know, he's younger than I am. But I'm faster!
Kent: How old are you?
Earl: I'm 79 years old!
Kent: And how old is George?
Earl: He's 78!
Kent: Well, congratulations, Earl!
Earl: Thanks!

comprehensionitem.question: What is a marathon?
Who was the last person to finish the race?
Who is older, Earl or his friend George?
option: They are at the same age.

grammaritem.question: How long ___ it take you to run the race?
__ I the last person to finish?
My friend George is _______ than I am.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Ellen Williams. She's going to talk to us about the problem of pollution. Ellen, why is pollution a problem?
Ellen: Well, for one thing, pollution makes us sick.
Kathy: You mean, it's bad for our health?
Ellen: That's right. Pollution causes health problems. For example, if we breathe polluted air, we get sick.
Kathy: I see. And we also get sick if we drink polluted water.
Ellen: Yes.
Kathy: What else?
Ellen: Polluted water kills animals and fish.
Kathy: That's terrible!
Ellen: Pollution also kills plants, and plants give us clean air.
Kathy: Plants give us clean air?
Ellen: Yes. Plants and trees produce the air that we breathe. Pollution kills the plants which give us clean air.

comprehensionitem.question: Which of these is not an example of pollution?
What happens if we breathe polluted air?
Why are plants and trees important to human life?
option: They produce the air that we breathe.
They produce clean water to drink.
comprehensionitem.answer: They produce the air that we breathe.

grammaritem.question: Pollution ______ health problems.
________ water kills animals and fish.
Pollution kills the plants _____ give us clean air.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Ellen, what causes air pollution?
Ellen: There are many causes of air pollution. Automobiles are one major cause of air pollution.
Kathy: What about factories? Do factories cause pollution?
Ellen: Yes, factories cause lots of pollution. Factories cause air pollution. They also cause water pollution.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0410B_Q1.mp3|What is one major cause of air pollution?
NDE0410B_Q2.mp3|Do factories cause pollution?
option: Yes. They cause both air pollution and water pollution.
They cause air pollution, but not water pollution.
comprehensionitem.answer: Yes. They cause both air pollution and water pollution.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0410B_Q3.mp3|What would happen if there were fewer automobiles?

grammaritem.answer: Automobiles are one major cause of air pollution.
Factories cause both air pollution and water pollution.
There are many causes of air pollution.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Do all automobiles cause pollution?
Ellen: That's a good question. All automobiles cause some pollution. In general, new cars cause less pollution than old cars. And big cars usually cause more pollution than small cars.

comprehensionitem.question: According to Ellen, do all automobiles cause pollution?
Which cause more pollution, old cars or new cars?
Is it true that big cars usually cause more pollution than small cars?
option: No. Large cars cause less pollution.
Pollution is not caused by automobiles.

grammaritem.question: Do all automobiles _____ pollution?
New cars cause less pollution less than ___ cars.
Big cars usually cause more pollution ____ small cars.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Max: Hi, Kathy. Who's our guest today?
Kathy: Denise Collins. Remember, she's the receptionist at a law firm. She's married and she has two children. This morning she took her children to the Natural History Museum.
Kathy: How are you today, Denise?
Denise: Fine, thanks.
Kathy: Did your kids enjoy their visit to the museum?
Denise: Oh, yes. They saw lots of interesting things.
Kathy: What did they like best?
Denise: They liked the dinosaurs best. We learned about different kinds of dinosaurs.
Kathy: Dinosaurs were very big, weren't they?
Denise: Not all of them were big. There were big dinosaurs and there were small dinosaurs.
Kathy: What did they eat?
Denise: Most dinosaurs ate plants, but some dinosaurs ate meat.

comprehensionitem.question: Where did Denise go with her children?
Were there any small dinosaurs?
option: Yes, there were. Some dinosaurs were small.
No, there weren't. All dinosaurs were very large.
comprehensionitem.answer: Yes, there were. Some dinosaurs were small.

comprehensionitem.question: What did dinosaurs eat?
option: Some dinosaurs ate plants, and others ate meat.
comprehensionitem.answer: Some dinosaurs ate plants, and others ate meat.

grammaritem.question: Did your kids enjoy _____ visit to the museum?
Dinosaurs were very big, _______ they?
Most dinosaurs ate plants, but some dinosaurs ___ meat.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Denise, I have a question for you. Why did the dinosaurs die?
Denise: They died because conditions changed.
Kathy: What do you mean?
Denise: The earth suddenly became cold and dark.
Kathy: What caused the change? Why did the earth suddenly become colder?
Denise: About sixty-five million years ago, a very large meteor hit the Earth.
Kathy: A meteor?
Denise: Yes, a rock from space. When the meteor hit the earth, dirt and dust went into the air. The dirt and dust stopped the sunlight.
Denise: So without heat and light from the sun, the Earth became cold and dark.
Kathy: The dinosaurs died because it was too cold?
Denise: That's right.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0411B_Q1.mp3|What happened on earth about sixty-five million years ago?
option: A very large meteor hit the earth.
The first dinosaurs appeared on earth.
comprehensionitem.answer: A very large meteor hit the earth.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0411B_Q2.mp3|Why couldn't heat and light from the sun reach the earth?
option: When the meteor hit the earth, dirt and dust went into the air.
The earth moved farther away from the sun.
The earth became cold and dark.
comprehensionitem.answer: When the meteor hit the earth, dirt and dust went into the air.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0411B_Q3.mp3|How did the dinosaurs die?
option: They died because the earth became too cold.
The Earth was too hot for them.
comprehensionitem.answer: They died because the earth became too cold.

grammaritem.answer: Why did the Earth become colder?
Without heat and light from the sun, the Earth became cold and dark.
The dinosaurs died because it was too cold.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Did all the dinosaurs die because it was too cold?
Denise: Well, some dinosaurs died from the cold. Other dinosaurs died because they didn't have enough to eat.
Kathy: Why didn't they have enough to eat?

Denise: You see, most dinosaurs ate plants. Plants need heat and light. When the earth became cold and dark, many plants died. And when the plants died, the dinosaurs didn't have enough to eat, and they died.

comprehensionitem.question: What do most dinosaurs eat?
Why didn't the dinosaurs have enough to eat?
option: When the Earth became cold and dark, many plants died.
The animals moved to warmer places.
comprehensionitem.answer: When the Earth became cold and dark, many plants died.

comprehensionitem.question: What happened to the dinosaurs when the plants died?
option: The dinosaurs didn't have enough to eat and they died.
The dinosaurs began to eat meat.
The dinosaurs fought with each other.
comprehensionitem.answer: The dinosaurs didn't have enough to eat and they died.

grammaritem.question: Some dinosaurs died _______ they didn't have enough to eat.
Why didn't the dinosaurs ____ enough to eat?
Plants need ____ and light to live.

mainlistitem.desc: Do you like to go hunting?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 12: Do you like to go hunting?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sandy Steele. Hi, Sandy. Welcome back.
Sandy: Hi, Kathy. It's nice to be back.
Kathy: Sandy, we know that you like to go fishing. How about hunting? Do you like to go hunting?
Sandy: Well, when I was a boy, I went hunting every summer with my father. We went duck hunting.
Kathy: Did you enjoy hunting?
Sandy: Yes, I did. I liked being outdoors with my Dad.
Kathy: Do you still go hunting?
Sandy: Not very often. But sometimes... sometimes I go hunting.
Kathy: Do you own a gun?
Sandy: Yes, I do. I own a gun, for hunting.

comprehensionitem.question: When he was a child, who did Sandy go hunting with?
How often does he go hunting now?
option: He doesn't go hunting any more.

comprehensionitem.question: Does Sandy own a gun?
option: He used to but he doesn't anymore.

grammaritem.question: I ____________ every summer with my father.
I liked _____ outdoors with my Dad.
Do you ___ a gun?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Sandy, many Americans feel that guns are bad. They think it is wrong for people to own guns.
Sandy: Well, I don't agree. I like to go hunting. I need a gun to go hunting. I don't think it is wrong for people to own guns.
Kathy: What about guns in people's homes? Many Americans think it is dangerous for people to have guns in their homes. Do you think so?
Sandy: No, I don't. I don't think it is dangerous for people to have guns in their homes.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0412B_Q1.mp3|How does Sandy feel about guns?
option: He doesn't think it's wrong for people to own guns.
He thinks it's wrong for people to own guns.
comprehensionitem.answer: He doesn't think it's wrong for people to own guns.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0412B_Q2.mp3|Why does Sandy feel that he needs to own a gun?
option: He needs a gun to go hunting.
He needs a gun for safety.
comprehensionitem.answer: He needs a gun to go hunting.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0412B_Q3.mp3|What does Sandy think about people having guns in their homes?
option: He thinks all Americans should own guns.

grammaritem.answer: Many Americans think it is wrong for people to own guns.
I need a gun to go hunting.
I don't think it's wrong for people to own guns.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Now it's time for a phone call. Hello. You're on the air with New Dynamic English.
Mary: Hello. My name is Mary. I'm from Chicago. Each year, guns kill thousands of people. If we control guns, we can save lives.
Sandy: I don't agree. The problem is criminals, not guns. If there were no guns, there would still be criminals.
Mary: Well, criminals use guns. And guns kill people. If criminals didn't have guns, everyone would be much safer.

comprehensionitem.question: Which of these statements would Mary agree with?
option: If we control guns, we can save lives.
The problem is criminals, not guns.
Everyone has a right to own a gun.
comprehensionitem.answer: If we control guns, we can save lives.

comprehensionitem.question: Who feels that everyone would be safer if there were fewer guns?
How do Sandy and Mary feel about the subject of gun control?
option: Sandy is in favor of gun control and Mary is opposed.

grammaritem.question: If we control guns, we can save _____.
If there were _______, there would still be criminals.
If criminals ___________ guns, everyone would be much safer.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is Kent Moss, the New Dynamic English Man on the Street. I'm standing outside the Natural History Museum. With me is Ella Schoeffer-Wolf, who is nine years old. Ella, tell us why you're here.
Ella: Well... I wrote a poem for a poetry contest. The contest was called "River of Words." And I won a trip to Washington, D.C.
Kent: And what was your poem about?
Ella: Fish.
Kent: Fish. Now, why did you write about fish?
Ella: Well... we had to write about something in nature, you know, like the ocean, or rain, or animals. So I chose fish, because I want people to love fish.
Kent: You want people to love fish?
Ella: Yes, because people pollute the water that fish live in, and then the fish die. I think if people love fish, then maybe they won't pollute the oceans and rivers.
Kent: I hope you're right, Ella. Well, it's been very nice talking with you. Good luck in the future!
Ella: Thank you.

comprehensionitem.question: How old is Ella?
What did Ella do?
Why does Ella want people to love fish?
option: So that they won't pollute oceans and rivers.
So that they won't eat fish.
So that they won't go fishing.
comprehensionitem.answer: So that they won't pollute oceans and rivers.

grammaritem.question: Why ___ you write about fish?
People pollute the water ____ fish live in.
If people love fish, they _____ pollute the oceans and rivers.
